      • getColorIndex

        public java.lang.Number getColorIndex()

      • setLevel

        public void setLevel(java.lang.Number level)
        An optional level index of where to place the node. The defaults behaviour is to place it next to the preceding node. Alias of nodes.column, but in inverted sankeys and org charts, the levels are laid out as rows.

      • getLevel

        public java.lang.Number getLevel()

      • setColor

      • setDataLabels

        public void setDataLabels(java.util.ArrayList dataLabels)
        Individual data label for each node. The options are the same as the ones for series.sankey.dataLabels.

      • getDataLabels

        public java.util.ArrayList getDataLabels()

      • setColumn

        public void setColumn(java.lang.Number column)
        An optional column index of where to place the node. The defaults behaviour is to place it next to the preceding node. Note that this option name is counter intuitive in inverted charts, like for example an organization chart rendered top down. In this case the "columns" are horizontal.

        Try it:

         •  Specified node column

      • getColumn

        public java.lang.Number getColumn()

      • setOffset

        public void setOffset(java.lang.Object offset)
        In a horizontal layout, the vertical offset of a node in terms of weight. Positive values shift the node downwards, negative shift it upwards. In a vertical layout, like organization chart, the offset is horizontal. If a percantage string is given, the node is offset by the percentage of the node size plus nodePadding.

        Try it:

         •  Specified node offset

        defaults:

         0

      • getOffset

        public java.lang.Object getOffset()

      • setId

        public void setId(java.lang.String id)
        The id of the auto-generated node, refering to the from or to setting of the link.

      • getId

        public java.lang.String getId()

      • setName

        public void setName(java.lang.String name)
        The name to display for the node in data labels and tooltips. Use this when the name is different from the id. Where the id must be unique for each node, this is not necessary for the name.

        Try it:

         •  Sankey diagram with node options

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()

      • setImage

        public void setImage(java.lang.String image)
        An image for the node card, will be inserted by the defaults dataLabel.nodeFormatter.

        Try it:

         •  Org chart with images

      • getImage

        public java.lang.String getImage()

      • setTitle

        public void setTitle(java.lang.String title)
        The job title for the node card, will be inserted by the defaults dataLabel.nodeFormatter.

        Try it:

         •  Org chart with job titles

      • getTitle

        public java.lang.String getTitle()

      • setLayout

        public void setLayout(java.lang.String layout)
        Layout for the node's children. If hanging, this node's children will hang below their parent, allowing a tighter packing of nodes in the diagram.

        Try it:

         •  Hanging layout

        defaults:

         normal

      • getLayout

        public java.lang.String getLayout()

      • setDefinition

        public void setDefinition(java.lang.String definition)
        The job description for the node card, will be inserted by the defaults dataLabel.nodeFormatter.

        Try it:

         •  Org chart with job descriptions

      • getDefinition

        public java.lang.String getDefinition()

      • setMass

        public void setMass(java.lang.Number mass)
        Mass of the node. By defaults, each node has mass equal to it's marker radius . Mass is used to determine how two connected nodes should affect each other: Attractive force is multiplied by the ratio of two connected nodes; if a big node has weights twice as the small one, then the small one will move towards the big one twice faster than the big one to the small one .

        Try it:

         •  Mass determined by marker.radius

      • getMass

        public java.lang.Number getMass()
